THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
In The Supreme Court


  
    
      
In the Matter of Gene C. Wilkes, Jr.,       
Respondent.
      
    
  


Opinion No. 25836
Heard April 8, 2004 - Filed June 14, 
  2004

DISBARRED


  
    
      
Henry B. Richardson, Jr., Disciplinary Counsel, 
  and Barbara M. Seymour, Assistant Disciplinary Counsel, both of Columbia, for 
  the Office of Disciplinary Counsel.
Thomas C. Brittain, of Myrtle Beach, for Respondent.
      
    
  


PER CURIAM: This attorney disciplinary matter 
  consolidates multiple matters.Â  After a hearing, the subpanel recommended Respondent 
  be disbarred.Â  We agree with the subpanel, and disbar Respondent from the practice 
  of law in this State.
PROCEDURAL HISTORY
Respondent was placed on interim suspension on June 
  27, 2002, and Formal Charges were filed on May 20, 2003.Â  Respondent did not 
  file an answer, and was held in default by consent order dated July 1, 2003.Â  
  Pursuant to Rule 24(a) of Rule 413, SCACR, the factual allegations in the Formal 
  Charges are deemed admitted by Respondent.
There are multiple matters, which were 
  consolidated for hearing purposes by the subpanel.Â  The following matters involving 
  misconduct are before this Court: 
I.Â Â Â Â Â Â  Real Estate Matter A
A married couple owned a condominium 
  as tenants in common in Horry County.Â  The husband died in December 1997, leaving 
  his wife as his only heir.Â  No documents were filed in Horry County to effectuate 
  the transfer of husbandâ€™s half interest in the condominium to the wife. 
 On July 6, 1998, Respondent closed on 
  the sale of the condominium without discovering or correcting the title defect.Â  
  Respondent also failed to discover an outstanding tax lien on the property.Â  
  The deed, which was filed on July 7, 1998, contained an erroneous property description 
  and an incorrect date.
Some time shortly after the closing, 
  a nonlawyer assistant in Respondentâ€™s office discovered the error in the property 
  description.Â  The assistant prepared a corrective deed showing the correct property 
  description.Â  The assistant had the corrected deed executed and filed without 
  consulting Respondent.Â  The corrective deed contained a number of errors, including 
  the lack of a date for the execution of the corrective deed, incorrect recording 
  and execution dates of the original deed, and an incorrect reference number.
In January 2001, Respondent attempted 
  to clear the title.Â  His nonlawyer assistant prepared a second corrective deed, 
  which contained some of the same errors as the first corrective deed, and omitted 
  any reference to the first corrective deed.Â  The second corrective deed was 
  prepared at the direction of Respondent, but without his review or supervision.
The subpanel found Respondent violated 
  the following Rules of Professional Conduct found in Rule 407, SCACR: Rule 1.1 
  (Competence); Rule 1.3 (Diligence); Rule 5.3 (Responsibilities Regarding Nonlawyer 
  Assistants); and Rule 5.5 (Unauthorized Practice of Law). 
The subpanel also found that Respondent failed to fully cooperate 
  with Disciplinary Counselâ€™s investigation, in violation of Rule 8.1 of the Rules 
  of Professional Conduct because Respondent failed to respond to the written 
  Notice of Full Investigation and failed to produce requested documents to the 
  Attorney to Assist and to the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC).Â  However, 
  the subpanel acknowledged that Respondent did appear for an interview pursuant 
  to Rule 19(c)(4), RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR, and did produce the closing file in 
  response to Disciplinary Counselâ€™s subpoena.Â  
The subpanel determined that Respondent 
  is subject to discipline in connection with Real Estate Matter A pursuant to 
  Rules 7(a)(1), 7(a)(3), 7(a)(5), and 7(a)(6) of RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.
II.Â Â Â Â Â  Real Estate Matter B
John Smith hired Respondent to close 
  on the sale of a condominium in May 2000.Â  At the time of the closing it was 
  discovered that Smith jointly held title with his deceased sister. 
 Respondent could not attend the closing; 
  therefore, he secured the services of another attorney.Â  That attorney retained 
  approximately $10,000, which was half of the proceeds of the sale, until the 
  issue was resolved.Â  He also withheld $1,000 to cover repairs for which, by 
  the time of the closing, Smith had already paid for directly.Â  Respondent also 
  agreed to resolve the probate matter and clear the title to the property, and 
  the other attorney withheld $525 at closing for that purpose. Following the 
  closing, the other attorney transferred the withheld funds to Respondent.Â  
The subpanel found that Smith still has 
  not received the full amount of funds withheld at closing, though Respondent 
  returned the $1,000 withheld for repairs following a year of phone calls from 
  Smith.Â  Smith was forced to hire another attorney to resolve the title issues.Â  
  Further, in November 2001 and in January and April 2002, the balance in Respondentâ€™s 
  trust account fell below the amount he was supposed to be holding in trust on 
  Smithâ€™s behalf. 
The subpanel found that Respondentâ€™s conduct in 
  this regard violated the following Rules of Professional Conduct found in Rule 
  407, SCACR: Rule 1.1 (Competence); Rule 1.2 (Scope of Representation); Rule 
  1.3 (Diligence); Rule 1.4 (Communication); Rule 1.5 (Fees); Rule 1.15 (Safekeeping 
  of Property); and Rule 1.16 (Declining or Terminating Representation).
The subpanel further found that Respondent 
  failed to fully cooperate with the disciplinary investigation in violation of 
  Rule 8.1 of the Rules of Professional Conduct, in that he did not respond to 
  the initial inquiries of Disciplinary Counsel and did not timely respond to 
  the Notice of Full Investigation.Â  The subpanel found that Respondent did appear 
  for an interview pursuant to Rule 19(c)(4), RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR, and complied 
  with a subpoena for Smithâ€™s file.
The subpanel determined that Respondent 
  is subject to discipline pursuant to Rules 7(a)(1), 7(a)(3), 7(a)(5), and 7(a)(6) 
  of RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.
III.Â Â Â Â  Tax Conviction Matter
Respondent was arrested in June 2001 
  on thirteen warrants arising from a South Carolina Department of Revenue investigation.Â  
  On July 24, 2002, Respondent pled guilty to one count of willful failure to 
  file an individual income tax return and was sentenced to one year imprisonment, 
  suspended upon three years probation and a fine of $1,500, plus assessments.Â  
  ODC entered into evidence a certified copy of the plea agreement, judgment, 
  and sentence.Â  
Respondent 
  did not report his arrest to ODC or to the Court, did not respond to ODCâ€™s inquiries 
  into the matter, and did not respond to the subsequent Notice of Full Investigation.Â  
  Respondent invoked his Fifth Amendment rights and did not respond to questions 
  regarding the matter at the Rule 19(c)(4) appearance.Â  
The subpanel found that Respondentâ€™s 
  conduct violated the following Rules of Professional Conduct found in Rule 407, 
  SCACR: Rule 8.4(b) (Misconduct-Criminal Act); Rule 8.4(d) (Misconduct-Conduct 
  Involving Dishonesty, Deceit, and Misrepresentation); and Rule 8.4(e) (Misconduct-Prejudice 
  to the Administration of Justice).Â  The subpanel also found that Respondent 
  failed to fully cooperate with the disciplinary investigation in violation of 
  Rule 8.1 of the Rules of Professional Conduct because Respondent made no attempt 
  to respond to the Notice of Full Investigation after his conviction.Â  Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  

The subpanel determined that Respondent is subject to discipline 
  pursuant to Rules 7(a)(1), 7(a)(3), 7(a)(4), and 7(a)(5) of RLDE, Rule 413, 
  SCACR.
IV.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  Probate Matter
Respondent represented Mrs. Doe, who 
  was the personal representative of her late husbandâ€™s intestate estate.Â  That 
  estate included $45,000 in proceeds from the sale of a condominium that Mr. 
  and Mrs. Doe owned jointly.Â  Respondent received the proceeds in November 2000, 
  but failed to distribute them to Mrs. Doe.Â  Respondent failed to respond to 
  Mrs. Doeâ€™s inquiries for a year.Â  Mrs. Doe then sent Respondent a certified 
  letter releasing him as her attorney and demanding that he release the funds 
  and provide her with an accounting.Â  
Mrs. Doe filed a petition for an order requiring 
  Respondent to deposit the money with the probate court and to pay her fees and 
  costs.Â  Her new attorney also requested an emergency hearing, and the court 
  issued a rule to show cause on March 1, 2002.Â  On March 6, 2002, Mrs. Doe received 
  a cashierâ€™s check in the amount of $45,000 from Respondent, and she withdrew 
  her request for an emergency hearing.Â  During the time Respondent was supposed 
  to be safekeeping Mrs. Doeâ€™s money, the balance in his trust account fell below 
  $45,000 on twenty-one occasions.Â  
Mrs. Doeâ€™s attorney appeared at the hearing and 
  testified regarding the status of and costs associated with the probate matter.Â  
  She stated that, although Mrs. Doe ultimately received the funds entrusted to 
  Respondent, Mrs. Doe has not been compensated for her costs and fees, which 
  total approximately $5,000.
The subpanel found that Respondent violated 
  the following Rules of Professional Conduct found in Rule 407, SCACR: Rule 1.3 
  (Diligence); Rule 1.4 (Communication); Rule 1.15 (Safekeeping of Property); 
  Rule 1.16 (Declining or Terminating Representation); and Rule 8.4(d) (Misconduct-Conduct 
  Involving Dishonesty, Fraud, Deceit, or Misrepresentation).
The subpanel found that Respondent violated 
  these rules in that he did not respond to or comply with the demands in Mrs. 
  Doeâ€™s letter, and that he did not respond to repeated inquiries from Mrs. Doeâ€™s 
  new attorney.
The subpanel further found that Respondent 
  failed to fully cooperate with the disciplinary investigation, in violation 
  of Rule 8.1 of the Rules of Professional Conduct, in that Respondent failed 
  to respond to the Notice of Full Investigation in this matter.Â  Respondent did 
  appear for a Rule 19(c)(4), RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR, interview, and responded 
  to the allegations under oath.Â  However, the subpanel found that Respondent 
  failed to comply with a subpoena for the production of the Doe client file and 
  financial records related to the above transaction.Â Â Â  
The subpanel found that Respondent is subject to 
  discipline for his conduct in the Probate Matter pursuant to Rules 7(a)(1), 
  7(a)(3), 7(a)(5), and 7(a)(6) of RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  
V.Â Â Â Â Â  Jones and Title Insurance Matters
Respondent 
  conducted a real estate closing for Mr. and Mrs. Jones on May 31, 2002.Â  Respondent 
  issued the Jones a check for $86,025.40 for the proceeds of the sale, which 
  was returned for insufficient funds.
The 
  Jonesâ€™s attorney, who also represents Mrs. Doe, testified at the hearing that 
  the Jones have not yet received any funds as compensation for the $86,025.40 
  in proceeds from the sale.Â  In addition, the Jones have incurred approximately 
  $5,000 in attorneysâ€™ fees and litigation costs, though the Jonesâ€™s real estate 
  agent refunded the $2,000 commission they paid to him.Â  At the time of Respondentâ€™s 
  interim suspension in June 2002, the funds remaining in Respondentâ€™s trust account 
  were not sufficient to cover the amount due.Â Â  
The 
  subpanel found that Respondent violated the following Rules of Professional 
  Conduct found in Rule 407, SCACR, in connection with the Jones matter: Rule 
  1.4 (Communication); Rule 1.15 (Safekeeping of Property); and, Rule 1.16 (Declining 
  or Terminating Representation).Â  
Moreover, in connection with the Jones matter, it was discovered that 
  Respondent failed to remit title insurance premiums on behalf of many of his 
  clients.Â  Respondent was an agent licensed by the Attorneysâ€™ Title Insurance 
  Fund, Inc., to issue title policies.Â  In approximately 150 cases, Respondent 
  collected title insurance premiums without issuing policies or paying the Fund. 
  [1]   
The subpanel based its estimate on the notes and partial records of Respondentâ€™s 
  staff because the attorney appointed to protect clientsâ€™ interests was unable 
  to recover most of Respondentâ€™s client files or other records.Â  The subpanel 
  noted that Respondent was found to be in contempt of the Supreme Court for destroying 
  his financial records, client records, and computers to avoid compliance with 
  ODC subpoenas.Â  The subpanel also noted that the Court found Respondent failed 
  to cooperate with the attorney appointed to protect clientsâ€™ interests and failed 
  to comply with an order of the Commission on Lawyer Conduct.
The subpanel found that Respondentâ€™s conduct in connection with the Title Insurance 
  Matters violated the following Rules of Professional Conduct found in Rule 407, 
  SCACR: Rule 1.1 (Competence); Rule 1.2 (Scope of Representation); Rule 1.3 (Diligence); 
  Rule 1.15 (Safekeeping of Property) Rule 1.16 (Declining or Terminating Representation); 
  Rule 8.4(a) (Misconduct-Violation of Rules of Professional Conduct); Rule 8.4(d) 
  (Misconduct-Conduct Involving Dishonesty, Fraud, Deceit, or Misrepresentation); 
  and Rule 8.4(e) (Misconduct-Prejudice to the Administration of Justice).
The subpanel found that Respondentâ€™s conduct in connection with the destruction 
  of records violated the following Rules of Professional Conduct found in Rule 
  407, SCACR: Rule 8.4(b) (Misconduct-Criminal Act); Rule 8.4(d) (Misconduct-Conduct 
  Involving Dishonesty, Fraud, Deceit, or Misrepresentation); and Rule 8.4(e) 
  (Misconduct-Prejudice to the Administration of Justice).Â  
The subpanel also found that Respondent violated the following Rules for 
  Lawyer Disciplinary Enforcement, found in Rule 413, SCACR: Rule 30 (Duties Following 
  Disbarment or Suspension); and Rule 31 (Appointment of Attorney to Protect Clientsâ€™ 
  Interests When Lawyer is Transferred to Incapacity Inactive Status, Suspended, 
  Disbarred, Disappears, or Dies). 
The subpanel found that Respondentâ€™s conduct in connection with the Jones 
  and Title Insurance Matters is subject to discipline in connection with Rules 
  7(a)(1), 7(a)(3), 7(a)(4), 7(a)(5), 7(a)(6), and 7(a)(7) of RLDE, Rule 413, 
  SCACR.Â Â  
VI.Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â Â  
  Mitigation
Counsel 
  for Respondent submitted affidavits from Respondentâ€™s mother and his psychiatrist.Â  
  The affidavits state that Respondent suffers from lifelong attention deficit 
  disorder, major depressive episode, and alcohol dependence.Â  Respondent is currently 
  seeking treatment for these conditions, including medication and psychotherapy.Â  
  Counsel for Respondent stated that this information was not presented as an 
  excuse or justification for his misconduct, but rather as an explanation.
RECOMMENDATION
The 
  subpanel recommended disbarment for Respondent, citing Respondentâ€™s conviction 
  for failure to file a tax return; the contempt order from this Court; Respondentâ€™s 
  pattern of neglect, incompetence, and failure to adequately communicate with 
  his clients; the significant financial losses arising from Respondentâ€™s misconduct; 
  and, Respondentâ€™s repeated failure to cooperate with the disciplinary investigations.Â  

Respondent 
  acknowledged that disbarment is the appropriate sanction.Â  However, Respondent 
  requested that the disbarment be made retroactive to June 27, 2002, the date 
  of his interim suspension.Â  Disciplinary Counsel did not object to the request. 

 The 
  subpanel also requested that any Order disbarring Respondent from the practice 
  of law include a provision that Respondent is not to be reinstated or readmitted 
  until: (1) he has served his probation and paid fines and assessments ordered 
  in the tax matter; (2) he has compensated all persons or entities who have suffered 
  financial losses as a result of his misconduct; and, (3) he has demonstrated 
  that his mental condition and alcohol dependence are no longer impediments to 
  his ability to practice law.Â  
The 
  subpanel further recommended that Respondent be assessed the costs of this proceeding, 
  pursuant to Rule 7(b)(8), Rule 413, SCACR.Â  The costs incurred were $462.21.
CONCLUSION
The 
  authority to discipline attorneys and the manner in which discipline is given 
  rests entirely with the Supreme Court.Â  In re Long, 346 S.C. 110, 551 
  S.E.2d 586 (2001).Â  The Court may make its own findings of fact and conclusions 
  of law, and is not bound by the Panelâ€™s recommendation.Â  In re Larkin, 
  336 S.C. 366, 520 S.E.2d 804 (1999).Â  The Court must administer the sanction 
  it deems appropriate after a thorough review of the record.Â  Id.
We 
  disbar Respondent from the practice of law in this state, retroactive to June 
  27, 2002.Â  Within six months of the date of this opinion, Respondent and Disciplinary 
  Counsel shall establish a restitution schedule, pursuant to which Respondent 
  shall make restitution to all persons and entities who have suffered financial 
  losses as a result of Respondentâ€™s misconduct, including, but not limited to, 
  Respondentâ€™s clients, the title insurance company, and the Lawyerâ€™s Fund for 
  Client Protection.Â  Failure to make restitution in accordance with this opinion 
  and the restitution plan may result in Respondent being held in contempt of 
  this Court.Â  Respondent shall not apply for readmission until restitution has 
  been paid in full, all civil matters pending against Respondent have been resolved 
  and all judgments are paid in full, and Respondent has served his probation 
  and paid fines and assessments ordered in the tax matter.Â  Further, Respondent 
  must remain on medication to control his condition.Â  
Within 
  fifteen (15) days of the date of this opinion, Respondent shall file an affidavit 
  with the Clerk of Court showing that he has complied with Rule 30 of Rule 413, 
  SCACR, and shall also surrender his Certificate of Admission to the Practice 
  of Law to the Clerk of Court.Â  Within ninety (90) days of the date of this opinion, 
  Respondent must pay the costs associated with this proceeding.Â  ($462.21).Â  

DISBARRED.
 TOAL, C.J., WALLER, BURNETT, PLEICONES, JJ., and Acting 
  Justice Paula H. Thomas, concur.

 
   
    [1]  Counsel for the Fund testified that he had identified only twenty-nine 
    cases in which Respondent had accepted premiums and failed to issue policies, 
    and that the costs of rechecking the titles and premiums and issuing new policies 
    totaled $8,783.99.Â  However, at the hearing, there was evidence that another 
    100 to 120 files for which Respondent had accepted money but not paid premiums 
    existed.Â

THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA

The State,

Appeal from Dorchester County
Rodney A. Peeples, Circuit Court Judge

Opinion No. 25838
Heard April 6, 2004 - Filed June 14,

AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART


  
    
      
Assistant Appellate Defenders 
  Robert M. Dudek and Eleanor Duffy Cleary, of South Carolina Office of Appellate 
  Defense, of Columbia, for appellant.
Attorney General Henry Dargan 
  McMaster, Chief Deputy Attorney General John W. McIntosh, and Assistant Deputy 
  Attorney General Donald J. Zelenka, of Columbia; and Solicitor Walter M. Bailey, 
  of Summerville, for respondent.
      
    
  


ACTING JUSTICE KITTREDGE:Â  
  Kenneth Simmons was convicted of murder, first degree burglary, armed robbery, 
  and first degree criminal sexual conduct.Â  He was sentenced to death and given 
  consecutive sentences of life and two thirty-year terms on the remaining charges.Â  
  We reverse the conviction and sentence for armed robbery, but otherwise affirm 
  Simmonsâ€™ convictions and sentences.
FACTS
On September 1, 1996, the 
  battered body of an eighty-nine-year-old female, whom we will refer to as Ms. 
  B, [1]  was found bound and gagged 
  on the kitchen floor of her home in Summerville.Â  She had been raped, severely 
  beaten, and strangled.Â  
The crime went unsolved 
  for more than a year until December 1997 when Simmons, who was incarcerated 
  on other charges, confessed to the killing.Â  He said he smoked crack and drank 
  beer at a club before riding his bicycle home in the early morning hours on 
  the day of the murder.Â  Simmons saw Ms. B in her yard feeding her chickens and 
  followed her into her house.Â  Simmons pushed her and demanded money.Â  Ms. B 
  fell to the floor and hit her head.Â  Simmons then hit her with a stick he had 
  picked up on the back porch.Â  He described the stick as being about two feet 
  long and an inch and a half or two inches in diameter.Â  Simmons raped Ms. B.Â  
  She was â€œhalf and halfâ€ alive when he fled the scene.Â  
The Stateâ€™s pathologist 
  testified Ms. B died from blunt trauma and manual strangulation.Â  She had multiple 
  rib fractures caused by stomping or slamming, severe head trauma, and severe 
  vaginal lacerations from the insertion of an object such as a stick or finger.Â  
  She had semen in her vagina and also in her mouth.Â  DNA testing indicated the 
  semen taken from Ms. Bâ€™s body was consistent with Simmonsâ€™ DNA.Â  
The jury found aggravating 
  circumstances of criminal sexual conduct, kidnapping, armed robbery, physical 
  torture, and burglary, and sentenced Simmons to death.Â  
ISSUES

  1.                 
  Did the State violate Doyle v. Ohio?
  2.                 
  Was a juror improperly dismissed after the trial had begun?
  3.                 
  Did the trial judge err in refusing to charge robbery as a lesser-included offense 
  of armed robbery?
  4.                 
  Was rebuttal evidence improperly excluded in the penalty phase?

DISCUSSION
1.Â  Doyle 
  v. Ohio
Because the Stateâ€™s case rested largely on Simmonsâ€™ 
  confession, the defense strategy during the guilt phase was to introduce expert 
  testimony that Simmons was not mentally capable of understanding and waiving 
  his Miranda [2]  rights.Â  

Dr. Jeffrey Vidic, a psychologist at the William 
  S. Hall Institute, [3]  along 
  with Dr. Thomas Behrman, a psychiatrist also employed at the Hall Institute, 
  attempted to evaluate Simmons for competency on November 23, 1998.Â  Drs. Vidic 
  and Behrman testified as defense witnesses.Â  Dr. Vidic was not satisfied Simmons 
  possessed the ability to comprehend his Miranda warnings and therefore 
  the competency exam could not proceed as planned.Â  Dr. Vidic stated he could 
  not formulate an opinion to a reasonable degree of certainty whether Simmons 
  actually understood his rights or whether he was â€œmalingering an inability to 
  understand his rights.â€Â  Dr. Behrmanâ€™s testimony lent further support to Simmonsâ€™ 
  position, for he stated, based on his November 23 observations, that Simmons 
  was not â€œable to explain his rightsÂ  . . . in a sufficient or meaningful fashion.â€Â  
  Dr. Behrman specifically opined that on November 23 Simmons â€œlacked the ability 
  to waive his rights for the purpose of the evaluation.â€ 
On cross-examination, Dr. Vidic testified over 
  Simmonsâ€™ objection that immediately after the aborted November 23 competency 
  exam, he left a note for his intern, Ms. Skaggs, asking her to administer psychological 
  tests to Simmons during a lunch break. The psychological testing requested by 
  Dr. Vidic did not involve the facts of the case.Â  Simmons refused to cooperate 
  with the testing administered by Ms. Skaggs, invoking his â€œrightâ€ to speak with 
  his lawyer.Â  The State elicited this testimony in response to Simmonsâ€™ position 
  that he lacked the ability to understand and exercise the Miranda warnings 
  and rights.
On appeal, Simmons argues the trial court erred 
  in allowing the prosecutorâ€™s cross-examination in violation of Doyle v. Ohio, 
  426 U.S. 610 (1976), and Wainwright v. Greenfield, 474 U.S. 284 (1986).Â  
  We disagree.
Doyle holds that the Due Process Clause 
  prohibits the government from commenting on an accused's post-Miranda 
  silence.Â  Doyle rests on â€œthe fundamental unfairness of implicitly assuring 
  a suspect that his silence will not be used against him and then using his silence 
  to impeach an explanation subsequently offered at trial.â€Â  South Dakota v. 
  Neville, 459 U.S. 553, 565 (1983).Â  This same concept of fundamental unfairness 
  prohibits the government from using a defendantâ€™s post-Miranda silence 
  as proof of sanity to overcome an insanity defense.Â  Wainwright v. Greenfield, 
  supra; see also State v. Smith, 290 S.C. 393, 350 S.E.2d 
  923 (1986).
Doyle does not, however, create a per se 
  rule requiring exclusion from evidence of a defendantâ€™s post-arrest, post-Miranda 
  silence in all circumstances.Â  As the Doyle court recognized:

It goes almost without saying that the fact of post-arrest 
  silence could be used by the prosecution to contradict a defendant who testifies 
  to an exculpatory version of events and claims to have told the police the same 
  version upon arrest.Â  In that situation the fact of earlier silence would not 
  be used to impeach the exculpatory story, but rather to challenge the defendantâ€™s 
  testimony as to his behavior following arrest.

Id. at 619, n.11.
In Anderson v. Charles, 447 U.S. 404 (1980), 
  the Court further clarifiedÂ  Doyle: 

Doyle does not apply to cross-examination that merely 
  inquires into prior inconsistent statements.Â  Such questioning makes no unfair 
  use of silence because a defendant who voluntarily speaks after receiving Miranda 
  warnings has not been induced to remain silent.Â  As to the subject matter of 
  his statements, the defendant has not remained silent at all.

447 U.S. at 408.Â  Other courts have found the Supreme 
  Courtâ€™s holding in Charles is not limited to situations involving inconsistent 
  statements.Â Â  See Splunge v Parke, 160 F.3d 369 (7th 
  Cir. 1998) (initial silence used to show police scrupulously honored defendantâ€™s 
  rights); Allen v. State, 686 N.E.2d 760 (Ind. 1997) (refusal to give 
  written statement after oral statement used to show rights respected); Commonwealth 
  v. Waite, 665 N.E.2d 982 (Mass. 1996) (reassertion of silence used to show 
  context in which questioning ended); State v. Correia, 707 A.2d 1245 
  (R.I. 1998) (same).Â  
The underpinnings of Doyle, and the need 
  for its application, are diminished where a defendant waives his right to silence.Â  
  Here, Simmons did not remain silent â€œas to the subject matter of his statements.â€Â  
  Simmons, following a waiver of his Miranda rights, confessed to the murder 
  of Ms. B in December 1997.Â  Following the lone invocation of his right to remain 
  silent in the context of the November 23, 1998, competency evaluation, Simmons 
  again waived his Miranda rights and cooperated with a January 1999 evaluation.Â  
  In this regard, in response to the defense strategy centered on Simmonsâ€™ purported 
  inability to comprehend the Miranda warnings, the Stateâ€™s targeted and 
  narrow use of Simmonsâ€™ recognition and exercise of his â€œrightâ€ to speak with 
  counsel did not breach the implied assurance contained in Miranda.Â  Simmons 
  asserted his right to silence only in the context of the November 23 psychological 
  examination.Â  The limited evidence of Simmonsâ€™ silence in this context was not 
  â€œdesigned to draw meaning from silenceâ€ regarding the substantive crime and 
  therefore does not violate Doyle.Â  Charles, 447 U.S. at 409.
This case is distinguishable from Greenfield.Â  
  In Greenfield the evidence of the defendantâ€™s silence was used as substantive 
  evidence of guilt in the prosecutionâ€™s case-in-chief because the defendant pled 
  not guilty by reason of insanity.Â  Here, the evidence of Simmonsâ€™ silence was 
  not offered as substantive evidence of guilt but as evidence of malingering 
  to rebut his claim that he was incapable of understanding his Miranda 
  rights.Â  
We thus conclude the Stateâ€™s use of evidence of 
  Simmonsâ€™ silence did not violate the fundamental fairness standard of Doyle.
2.Â  Dismissal of juror
After jury selection, the trial judge informed the jury about sequestration 
  and repeatedly admonished the jury not to discuss the case with anyone.Â  Contact 
  by jurors with family members, by telephone or otherwise, was to be monitored 
  by the SLED team in charge of security and sequestration.
Before the end of the guilt phase, information regarding Juror C was 
  brought to the courtâ€™s attention.Â  The trial judge noted for the record:Â  

Captain Polk of SLED received 
  a call from the wife of [Juror C] at which time the lady revealed to him that 
  she was very concerned because she realized that the sister of the defendant, 
  Kenneth Simmons, lived across the street from a piece of property that they 
  owned on Congress Street in the Town of Summerville.Â  And in the event that 
  the jury returned a verdict of guilty or imposed the death penalty and they 
  were going to build on a vacant lot across the street from the defendantâ€™s sister 
  that it would perhaps cause consternation, fear, concern, or whatever.Â  

The trial judge asked Captain 
  Polk to call Juror Câ€™s wife but Captain Polk was unable to immediately contact 
  her.
Meanwhile, the trial judge received a note from Juror C stating:

Your honor, I have realized that 
  I know a possible relative of the defendant, Kenneth Simmons, and asked earlier 
  in the week if I knew relatives of the accused, I truthfully answered no.Â  After 
  the trial started, I saw a woman I recognized sitting behind Kenneth Simmons.Â  
  I now realize the woman in the audience was, I believe, a Mrs. Louise that lives 
  opposite a vacant lot I own in the Town of Summerville on Congress Street.Â  
  In the future my wife and I intend to build on this lot our primary residence.Â  
  I have upon occasion been cordial with Mrs. Louise and say hello to her while 
  I am on or about my property.Â  Knowing Mrs. Louise will not influence my decision-making 
  ability regarding the guilt or innocence of Kenneth Simmons.Â  If the trial proceeds 
  to the penalty stage, none of the above will influence my decision-making ability 
  regarding life imprisonment or the death penalty as outlined in the pre-trial 
  questionnaire.Â  I felt it was my duty as a juror to inform you of the above 
  and to continue to serve you in any capacity you see fit.

Captain Polk then spoke with 
  Juror Câ€™s wife.Â  She told Captain Polk she had talked with her husband about 
  Simmonsâ€™ sister and stated she was upset, fearful, and â€œreally concerned.â€Â  
  Although Juror Câ€™s note was written after the improper conversation, the note 
  contained no reference to the conversation.
The State then moved to excuse Juror C.Â  Simmons requested that the trial judge 
  first question Juror C about the conversation with his wife.Â  The trial judge 
  questioned Juror C in chambers.Â  Juror C confirmed that he and his wife had 
  discussed the personal effect of a verdict in the case.Â  The trial judge explained 
  to Juror C that because he and his wife had discussed the case, he would be 
  excused from the case.Â  As a result of the â€œimproper communicationâ€ between 
  Juror C and his wife, Juror C was excused.Â  
On appeal, Simmons contends the trial court erred in dismissing Juror C since 
  the juror indicated he could maintain his impartiality.Â  We disagree.Â  Simmons 
  cites Greer v. Neville, 21 S.C.L. (3 Hill) 262 (1837), for the proposition 
  that once the jury has been sworn, the trial court cannot discharge a qualified 
  juror without legal cause absent the consent of both parties.Â  In Greer, 
  a juror was removed after being seated solely on the basis of counselâ€™s assertion 
  that the juror was biased against counsel and would not do his client justice.Â  
  There was no evidence to support counselâ€™s bald assertion, and our court of 
  appeals found the excusal of the juror arbitrary.
The court of appeals distinguished Greer in the case of Boland v. 
  Greenville and Columbia R.R. Co., 46 S.C.L. (12 Rich.) 368 (1859), wherein 
  a juror, who was the local coroner, was dismissed during trial because he was 
  needed to investigate a homicide.Â  The court noted it is within the trial courtâ€™s 
  discretion to substitute an alternate juror where there is a legal necessity 
  or there is disclosed during trial a disqualifying interest of a juryman.Â  Id. 

In this case, the record indicates Juror C discussed the case with his wife, 
  including the personal effect of a possible verdict, against the trial judgeâ€™s 
  express admonition not to do so.Â  We hold the trial judge acted within his discretion 
  in excusing Juror C for the jurorâ€™s unauthorized communication with his wife. 
  [4] Â  
3.Â  Robbery as a lesser-included offense
Upon the Stateâ€™s objection, the trial court refused Simmonsâ€™ request 
  to charge robbery as a lesser-included offense of armed robbery ruling that 
  â€œ[w]hile itâ€™s a true proposition of law . . . itâ€™s not applicable to the uncontradicted 
  facts.â€Â  Simmons contends this was error because the evidence indicates the 
  only weapons involved were fists and a stick, and whether either of these qualifies 
  as a â€œdeadly weaponâ€ is a question of fact for the jury.Â  The State argues that 
  since the victim died as a result of wounds inflicted by fists or a stick, these 
  are â€œdeadly weaponsâ€ as a matter of law. 
South Carolina Code Ann. Â§ 16-11-330(A) (Supp. 2003) defines armed 
  robbery in pertinent part as â€œrobbery while armed with a pistol, dirk, slingshot, 
  metal knuckles, razor, or other deadly weapon.â€ (emphasis added).Â Â Â  
  Whether an object has been used as a deadly weapon depends upon the facts and 
  circumstances of each case.Â  State v. Davis, 309 S.C. 326, 422 S.E.2d 
  133 (1992) (murder); [5]  see 
  also State v. Bennett, 328 S.C. 251, 493 S.E.2d 845 (1997) (fist 
  may be deadly weapon for purposes of armed robbery).Â  Despite the egregious 
  facts of this case, we adhere to the rule in Davis and hold that whether 
  the robbery was perpetrated with a deadly weapon was a question of fact for 
  the jury.Â Â  
 Although the trial court charged the jury that it was to determine 
  whether a deadly weapon was used, the court refused to give the jury the option 
  of convicting Simmons of the lesser offense of robbery.Â  This was error.Â  We 
  therefore reverse Simmonsâ€™ conviction and sentence for armed robbery.Â  See 
  Brightman v. State, 336 S.C. 348, 520 S.E.2d 614 (1999) (trial judge 
  must charge lesser-included offense if there is any evidence from which it can 
  be inferred the defendant committed lesser rather than greater offense).Â Â  
The real impetus in Simmonsâ€™ challenge to the failure to charge the lesser-included 
  offense is to invalidate the juryâ€™s finding of armed robbery as an aggravating 
  factor, and ultimately, invalidate the sentence of death.Â  While we agree that 
  the error requires us to vacate the invalid aggravator of armed robbery, the 
  error does not warrant reversal of the death sentence.Â  Succinctly stated, we 
  find Simmonsâ€™ death sentence is supported by other valid aggravators. 
In Zant v. Stephens, 462 U.S. 862 (1983), the Supreme Court held that 
  in states such as ours where aggravating and mitigating factors are not weighed 
  â€œpursuant to any special standard,â€ a death sentence may be upheld even where 
  one aggravator has been invalidated if there is a valid aggravator remaining. [6] Â  As the Court later explained in Tuggle 
  v. Netherland, 516 U.S. 10, 13 (1995), Zant was â€œpredicated on the 
  fact that even after elimination of the invalid aggravator, the death sentence 
  rested on firm ground.â€ Â To the contrary, in Tuggle, an aggravator was 
  invalidated because the defendant was precluded from developing rebuttal evidence 
  relevant in the penalty phase.Â  The Court concluded the evidentiary error could 
  have affected the juryâ€™s consideration of the death sentence even though another 
  aggravator was found.Â  We are confronted with no such evidentiary preclusion.
Here, the jury affirmatively found independent aggravators of criminal sexual 
  conduct, kidnapping, burglary, and physical torture, in addition to armed robbery.Â  
  There was no error in the admission or exclusion of evidence in the penalty 
  phase.Â  We conclude the invalidation of the armed robbery aggravator does not 
  impact the validity of the other aggravators found by the jury in this case, 
  and we reject Simmonsâ€™ challenge to his death sentence.
4.Â  Rebuttal evidence in penalty phase
In the penalty phase, the State presented victim impact evidence from 
  the victimâ€™s family and friends stating how they were negatively affected by 
  the victimâ€™s death.Â  During the defense case, Simmonsâ€™ cousin, Calvin Linning, 
  testified about positive features of Simmonsâ€™ character.Â  Linning then stated:Â  


Itâ€™s awfully hard for me to be 
  up here today because Iâ€™m certainly nervous because we know [the victim] personally.Â  
  I grew up in the Church of God in Summerville and [the victim] and my family 
  was real close.Â  We would take her to the State Youth Convention year after 
  year.Â  My brother is the one that taught her how to drive.Â  And my niece was 
  really close to [the victim].Â  She had a real close relationship with her.Â  
  And it was real painful when we discovered about her - 

At this point, the State objected 
  to Linningâ€™s testimony regarding â€œhis personal feelings about what occurred.â€Â  
  The objection was sustained.Â  Linning finished his testimony by asking the jury 
  to give Simmons a life sentence rather than death.Â  
Simmons contends it was a due process violation for the trial court 
  to disallow Linningâ€™s testimony that Simmonsâ€™ family suffered because of the 
  victimâ€™s death.Â  We disagree.Â  
First, this argument was not raised at trial and no proffer was 
  made as to what Linningâ€™s testimony would have been had he been allowed to continue.Â  
  This issue therefore is not preserved for review.Â  State v. Hughes, 336 
  S.C. 585, 521 S.E.2d 500 (1999) (to be preserved for appellate review, issue 
  must be raised and ruled upon in the trial court).Â  In any event, there was 
  no error.Â  
In Payne v. Tennessee, 501 U.S. 808 (1991), 
  the Supreme Court ruled victim impact evidence is admissible to show the victimâ€™s 
  uniqueness as an individual human being and the specific harm committed by the 
  defendant in murdering the victim.Â  This evidence is relevant for the jury to 
  meaningfully assess the defendantâ€™s moral culpability and blameworthiness.Â  
  State v. Byram, 326 S.C. 107, 485 S.E.2d 360 (1997).Â  Here, the impact 
  of the victimâ€™s death on Simmonsâ€™ family is not relevant rebuttal to the evidence 
  of Simmonsâ€™ moral culpability shown by the victim impact testimony.Â  We find 
  no due process violation. 
CONCLUSION
Pursuant to S.C. Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-25(C)(2003), we find the death sentence 
  in this case was not imposed under the influence of passion, prejudice, or any 
  other arbitrary factor; the evidence supports the juryâ€™s findings of aggravating 
  circumstances; and the sentence of death is neither excessive nor disproportionate 
  to the penalty imposed in similar cases.Â  See State v. Terry, 
  339 S.C. 352, 529 S.E.2d 274 (2000); State v. Conyers, 326 S.C. 263, 
  487 S.E.2d 181 (1997); State v. Whipple, 324 S.C. 43, 476 S.E.2d 683 
  (1996).Â  We reverse Simmonsâ€™ conviction and sentence for armed robbery and affirm 
  his remaining convictions and sentences.
 AFFIRMED IN PART; REVERSED IN PART.
 TOAL, C.J., WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.

 
   [1] We 
    elect not to identify the victim by name.

 
   
    [2] Â  Miranda v. Arizona, 384 U.S. 436 (1966).

 
   
    [3] Â  The William S. Hall Institute is the primary educational and research 
    facility for the South Carolina Department of Mental Health.Â  

 
   
    [4] Â  We emphasize this is not a case where a juror was removed for concealing 
    information during voir dire.Â  This jurorâ€™s self-proclaimed impartiality is 
    therefore not dispositive.Â  Cf. State v. Stone, 350 S.C. 442, 
    567 S.E.2d 244 (2002) (error to remove juror for innocently concealing information 
    where juror indicated her impartiality was not affected).

 
   
    [5]  Overruled on other grounds by Brightman v. State, 336 
    S.C. 348, 520 S.E.2d 614 (1999) (failure to give King charge not reversible 
    error).Â Â 

 
   
    [6] Â  Zant involved Georgiaâ€™s death penalty statute.Â  Georgiaâ€™s 
    statutory approach requires the factfinder to consider applicable aggravating 
    and mitigating circumstances, without regard to â€œany special standard.â€Â  Id. 
    at 873.Â  In weighing â€œaggravating and mitigating circumstances against each 
    other,â€ the Georgia statutory scheme is not â€œgoverned by any specific standards.â€Â  
    Id. at 875.Â  Under Georgia law, the factfinder retains â€œabsolute discretionâ€ 
    to impose a life sentence, notwithstanding the presence of an aggravating 
    circumstance.Â  Id. at 871.Â  South Carolinaâ€™s statutory scheme is in 
    accord, and we find the reasoning of Zant persuasive.Â  See S.C. 
    Code Ann. Â§ 16-3-20(B) (2003) (if statutory aggravating circumstance found, 
    defendant sentenced to either death or life imprisonment); State v. Hughey, 
    339 S.C. 439, 529 S.E.2d 721 (2000) (jury may recommend life imprisonment 
    for any reason or no reason at all); State v. Elkins, 312 S.C. 541, 
    436 S.E.2d 178 (1993) (under our capital sentencing scheme, jury does not 
    â€œweighâ€ aggravating circumstances; the failure of one aggravating circumstance 
    does not require reversal where there remains a valid aggravator).

The Supreme Court of South Carolina

  
    
      
In the Matter of Mark D.
Lattimore, Respondent.
      
    
  


ORDER

 Respondent 
  pled guilty to conspiracy to commit mail fraud in violation of 18 U.S.C. Â§ 1349.Â  
  The information charges that from on or about February 1, 2001, and continuing 
  through on or about August 15, 2002, respondent and his co-conspirators conspired 
  to deceive a mortgage company located in Ohio as to the actual value of real 
  properties located in South Carolina.Â  By inflating the value of the real properties 
  the mortgage company was considering for financing and refinancing transactions, 
  respondent and his co-conspirators fraudulently induced the mortgage company 
  to lend more money than it would have had the appraisals not been inflated and 
  to lend more money than the actual value of the real properties, all to the 
  personal enrichment of respondent and his co-conspirators in the form of inflated 
  fees, commissions, and profits.Â  In furtherance of the conspiracy, respondent 
  and his co-conspirators utilized private and commercial interstate carriers 
  to send and deliver real estate closing documents from South Carolina to Ohio.Â 
 

The Office of Disciplinary Counsel 
  petitions the Court to place respondent on interim suspension pursuant to Rule 
  17(b), RLDE, of Rule 413, SCACR.Â  Respondent consents to being placed on interim 
  suspension.
The petition is granted and respondent 
  is suspended, pursuant to Rule 17, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR, from the practice 
  of law in this State until further order of the Court.Â 
 
IT IS SO ORDERED.Â

text:
THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA



THE STATE OF SOUTH CAROLINA
  In The Supreme Court

 
   
     
      
        In the Matter of Laurie A. Baker, Respondent.
      
    
  


Opinion No. 25837
  Submitted April 26, 2004 - Refiled June 21, 2004

DEFINITE SUSPENSION

 
   
     
      
        Henry B. Richardson, Jr., and Barbara M. Seymour, both of Columbia, 
          for the Office of Disciplinary Counsel. 
        Desa A. Ballard, of West Columbia, for respondent.Â  
      
    
  


PER CURIAM:Â Â  In this attorney disciplinary matter, respondent 
  and the Office of Disciplinary Counsel (ODC) have entered into an Agreement 
  for Discipline by Consent pursuant to Rule 21, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  In the 
  agreement, respondent admits misconduct and consents to any sanction within 
  the range of an admonition to a three month definite suspension from the practice 
  of law.Â  See Rule 7, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.Â  We accept the agreement 
  and definitely suspend respondent from the practice of law in this state for 
  a three month period.Â  The facts, as set forth in the agreement, are as follows.Â  

FACTS
Matter I 
In May 1998, respondent graduated from law school andÂ  was admitted to the 
  North Carolina Bar three months later.Â  She was employed by the firm of Forquer 
  & Green in Charlotte, North Carolina.Â  After she was admitted to the South 
  Carolina Bar in August 1998, respondent was assigned to the firmâ€™s Rock Hill 
  law office.Â  Respondent was the only licensed attorney working in the Rock Hill 
  office of Forquer & Green.Â  
On September 1, 1999, Forquer & Green merged with the firm of Brock & 
  Scott.Â  In South Carolina, the firm operated as Green, Brock, Forquer & 
  Scott.Â  At the time of the merger, respondent became an employee of the new 
  law firm and was given a one percent interest in the firm.Â  
With the merger, three non-lawyer employees moved into the Rock Hill office.Â  
  The three employees included an unlicensed law school graduate (Mr. Brown) and 
  two legal assistants.Â  Respondent supervised all three employees.Â  
While employed at Green, Brock, Forquer & Scott, Mr. Brown conducted real 
  estate closings, both inside and outside of the office, without respondent or 
  another attorney being present.Â  Mr. Brown signed respondentâ€™s name on real 
  estate closing documents without indicating he was signing for her.Â  This was 
  done with respondentâ€™s knowledge and, in some cases, in her presence.Â  
After conducting real estate closings, it was Mr. Brownâ€™s practice to have 
  other firm employees sign as witness and/or notary on the documents even though 
  they were not present at the closings.Â  Mr. Brown also routinely signed as witness 
  and notary to documents related to closings at which he was not present.Â  Respondent 
  was not specifically aware of these practices; however, she admits she was responsible 
  for Mr. Brownâ€™s supervision.Â  
From September 1999 until January 2000, respondent and Mr. Brown handled approximately 
  sixty to eighty real estate closings per month.Â  Although respondent represents 
  she had concern, respondent made no meaningful inquiry into the propriety of 
  non-lawyers conducting real estate closings.Â  Respondent did not conduct any 
  legal research, consult with an attorney outside her firm, or seek guidance 
  from the South Carolina Bar concerning the propriety of a non-lawyers conducting 
  real estate closings.Â  
Matter II
On January 17, 2000, respondent left Green, Brock, Forquer & Scott.Â  As 
  a favor to the firm, however, respondent conducted a real estate closing in 
  Greenville for Complainants A and B.Â  Following the closing, respondent left 
  the closing documents in the firmâ€™s Rock Hill office and took no further action 
  in regard to the closing.Â  Where she had failed to sign her name on the closing 
  documents, Mr. Brown signed respondentâ€™s name, including on an affidavit and 
  a certification.Â  On one document, Mr. Brown notarized respondentâ€™s signature 
  when he had signed her name himself.Â  Mr. Brown signed his own name as witness 
  on the documents even though he was not present when the documents were executed.Â  
  Mr. Brown notarized Complainant Aâ€™s and Complainant Bâ€™s signatures in two places.Â  
  Some of the documents in the closing file were incomplete or left blank.Â  Mr. 
  Brown completed the documents and filled in the blanks.Â  
When Complainants A and B subsequently attempted to refinance the property, 
  they discovered the mortgage and deed had never been filed.Â  Respondent admits 
  she failed to adequately explain her limited role in connection with the closing.Â  
  She further admits she failed to ensure the closing documents where appropriately 
  completed and filed.Â Â Â Â  
LAW
Respondent admits that by her misconduct she has violated the following provisions 
  of the Rules of Professional Conduct, Rule 407, SCACR:Â  Rule 1.1 (lawyer shall 
  provide competent representation to client); Rule 1.2 (lawyer may limit objectives 
  of representation with client consent after consultation); Rule 5.3 (lawyer 
  having direct supervisory authority over non-lawyer employee shall make reasonable 
  efforts to ensure that the personâ€™s conduct is compatible with the professional 
  obligations of the lawyer; lawyer is responsible for conduct of non-lawyer employee 
  if the conduct would be a violation of the Rules of Professional Conduct if 
  engaged in by a lawyer and lawyer orders or, with the knowledge of the specific 
  conduct, ratifies the conduct involved); Rule 5.5 (lawyer shall not assist non-lawyer 
  in performance of activity which constitutes unauthorized practice of law); 
  Rule 8.4(a) (lawyer shall not violate Rules of Professional Conduct); Rule 8.4(d) 
  (lawyer shall not engage in conduct involving dishonesty, fraud, deceit or misrepresentation); 
  and Rule 8.4(e) (lawyer shall not engage in conduct that is prejudicial to administration 
  of justice). Â In addition, respondent admits her misconduct constitutes a violation 
  of Rule 7, RLDE, of Rule 413, SCACR, specifically Rule 7(a)(1) (lawyer shall 
  not violate Rules of Professional Conduct or any other rules of this jurisdiction 
  regarding professional conduct of lawyers), Rule 7(a)(5) (lawyer shall not engage 
  in conduct tending to pollute the administration of justice or to bring the 
  courts or the legal profession into disrepute or conduct demonstrating an unfitness 
  to practice law) and Rule 7(a)(6) (lawyer shall not violate the oath of office 
  taken upon admission to practice law in this state).Â Â  
CONCLUSION
We accept the Agreement for Discipline by Consent and definitely suspend respondent 
  from the practice of law for a three month period, effective on the date of 
  this opinion.Â  Within fifteen days of the date of this opinion, respondent shall 
  file an affidavit with the Clerk of Court showing that she has complied with 
  Rule 30, RLDE, Rule 413, SCACR.
DEFINITE SUSPENSION.
TOAL, C.J., MOORE, WALLER, BURNETT and PLEICONES, JJ., concur.
